cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENTPrinted for the War Cabinet. May 1940.SECRET.W.M. (40)139th Conclusions.Copy No.TO BE KEPT UNDER. LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 139 (40).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street,S.W. 1, on Sunday, May 26, 1940, at 9 a.m.9 Present :The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).R. Attlee, M.P.,The Right Hon. Neville Chamberlain,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. Viscount Halifax,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. C.Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon. A. Greenwood, M.P.,Minister without Portfolio.The following were also present:The Right Hon. A. V. Alexander,M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.The Right Hon. Viscount Caldecote,Secretary of State for DominionAffairs.The Hon. Sir Alexander Cadogan,Permanent Under-Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs.Admiral of the Fleet Sir dudley pound, First Sea Lord and Chief ofNaval Staff.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for War.The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,M.P., Secretary of State for theHome Department and Minister ofHome Security.The Right Hon. A. Duff Cooper, M.P.,Minister of Information.Air Chief Marshal Sir Cyril L. N.Newall, Chief of the Air Staff.General Sir W. Edmund Ironside,Chief of the Imperial General Staff.Air Marshal R. E. C. Peirse, Vice-Chief of the Air Staff.Secretariat.Sir Edward Bridges.Major-General H. L. Ismay.Lieutenant-Colonel V. Dykes, R.E.Group Captain W. Elliot.[21340] WAR CABINET 139 (40).Contents.minute no. Subject. page 1 The Western Front .................. 261Progress of operations.2 Defence Works .................. 261Priority for labour, machinery and materials.3 The Western Front .................. 261Information asked for by the Australian Prime Minister. The western front.Progress of operations.(previous reference erence:W.M. (40) 138thConclusions,Minute 1.)1. The Prime Minister informed the War Cabinet of the upshot of a Meeting of Service Ministers and Chiefs of Staff heldat 10 p.m. the previous night. At this Meeting the whole position had been reviewed in the light of the latest information. this information included : (1) A letter from General Spears, who had seen M. Reynaud,and bad attended what had been to all intents and purposes a meeting of the French War Cabinet.(2) A message from M. Reynaud to the Prime Minister.(3) An oral report from General Dill.(4) An oral report from General Karslake, who had seenBrigadier Swayne at G.Q.G. on Saturday, the 25th May.The War Cabinet were also informed that M. Reynaud was coming over to London in the course of that day, and would see thePrime Minister and some of his colleagues. It was arranged thatthe War Cabinet should meet again at 2 p.m.A full record of the discussion, and of the Conclusions reached,is contained in the Secretary's Standard File of War cabinet conclusions.Defence Works. 2. The Secretary of State for War asked that priority shouldPriority for be accorded to the labour, excavating machinery and other plantlabour, required for urgent defence works. The priority accorded should,machinery and he thought, be an absolute priority except in regard to work onmaterials. aerodromes.If this priority was accorded, the result would inevitably beto put back work on a number of Government factories. these factories, however, were part of our long-term programme, and itwould be in accordance with our present policy that the long-termproject should give way to the necessities of the immediate situation.The Minister without Portfolio, as Chairman of the Produc-tion Council, said that he agreed with the course proposed.The War Cabinet agreed : That, save in regard to work on aerodromes, priority should be accorded, until further notice, to the require-ments of labour and plant (e.g., excavating and concretingmachinery) for urgent defence works, subject to the adjustment of particular cases, at the discretion of theProduction Council.The Western 3. The Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs referred to atelegram from Mr. Menzies to the Australian High CommissionerInformation m London, asking for information, under eleven heads, in regard toasked for by the the situation on the Western Front. In present circumstances heAustralian felt somewhat indisposed to give Mr. Menzies the very detailedPrime Minister, information asked for.After discussion, the War Cabinet agreed : That the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs should inform Mr. Bruce that the information asked for wouldtake some time to collect.Richmond Terrace, S. W. 1,May 26, 1940.
